review_title: Low pay, great benefits, good work culture
job_title: Project Management Coordinator in Wilmington, NC
pros: The benefits can't be beat. Great health/vision/dental, generous PTO, and 3 course credits per year at any UNC institution. The culture is also pretty laid back and everyone is pretty nice. If you have a partner/roommate/family member who is the breadwinner and can support you, it's a pretty good job. Especially entry level positions.
cons: Low pay in an area with a high cost of living. Hard to save and pay your bills if you don't have someone else as the breadwinner and are just starting your career.

job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Wilmington, NC
pros: I enjoy my job and feel supported. Co workers are great and helpful. The environment is busy but even paced.
cons: Turnover is not helpful but somewhat unavoidable in this market.

review_title: The TAC is a great place to work!
job_title: Student IT Support Technician in Wilmington, NC

cons: You're very much limited to the position you are in and the work you are delegated, there isn't a huge amount of room for growth.

review_title: Overall Positive, Fairly Typical Public Higher Ed Experiences
pros: As a faculty member at UNCW, I have always felt I have a large degree of autonomy in all aspects of my job. As an administrator, I feel I still have fairly wide degrees of latitude to shape my day-to-day and my longer-term projects. Although UNCW is not immune to the pressures bearing down on higher ed across the country (i.e., declining enrollments), it feels somewhat insulated given its location (sunbelt, desirable location, etc.), at least relative to other non-major, non-flagship institutions.
cons: Pay stagnates without keeping up with inflation. Years can go by without raises, and when they come they are usually small. The higher levels of authority over UNCW and the UNC system appear increasingly willing to intervene in university governance in counterproductive ways.

pros: Great school and department. The division is very collaborative.

review_title: Beautiful campus but frustrating work environment
pros: The campus and the city are beautiful. The UNC system offers good benefits.
cons: UNCW has been one of the most frustrating places I've ever worked. My department has its own unique problems, but it seems the entire university lacks sufficient policies and protocols to address even minor concerns (ie. taking 6 weeks to get one piece of furniture moved, calls and emails to certain offices never getting answered, only having two buses for rental for the entire campus) to major (having internet servers located on campus in a hurricane-prone area). Vacant positions take forever to fill, and in the meantime, the understaffed office is expected to step in and absorb additional duties for 8-12 months (or more) with no extra pay. It seems that UNCW has taken the laid-back Wilmington "beach vibe" very literally, as there is no urgency to improve systems or retain good faculty/staff. It feels like the entire school is stuck in the 80's and committed to doing things "they way they've always been done" instead of progressing and looking to the future. In general, the campus has a very reactionary attitude, with a tendency to wait until things happen and then respond rather than trying to plan ahead and prevent problems. Some departments may be better than others, but this is my observation as a whole. Come to UNCW if you want to live in the beautiful city of Wimington, but expect to have your patience tested if you try to actually make any career progress at this school.

pros: I worked within Campus Life, and I would say that my overall experience was good. I met a lot wonderful people,  learned how to communicate with customers with a variety of particular customers, as well as how to better conduct myself in stressful situations.
cons: Working for Campus Life can be a lot of fun, but there were many times when it felt like they were expecting their employees to care a bit too much. Yes, they're paying you and it's a good experience, but you're getting paid barely over minimum wage to work less than 20hrs a week. For most people this job wont lead to a full-blown career. It's still a good job, just a little much at times. Also, they only pay people once a month.

pros: The freedom to explore the ever growing industry of D&I while taking our campus along for an enriching ride via my expertise and commitment to growth related to D&I.

review_title: No Empathy or Rapport For Students
pros: Close to the beach. Campus is pretty.
cons: Campus is pretty because they charge a $1000 a semester to every student that goes there, by now we should have a chocolate fountain the size of Texas. I don't like how faculty will blow students off if they dont know the answer or how to help someone. As well as majority of faculty thinking they are better than others. The pay is ridiculous when you can go work or a company that will offer you double. It didnt seem like the majority of teachers were there for the students, it was just all policy and procedure. To much over head.

pros: Mostly good people to work with.  Working within an institution of higher learning allows good discussions on many different topics.  Good balance between home and work life.
cons: No room for growth...upper management does not seem to listen to those who are not in a managerial role.  Salary is not competitive in some positions and departments are severely under staffed.  Often told to you have to do more with less and less each year. Benefits are not that good.

pros: Job security with one of the few actual employers in town and great state benefits. Able to leave work at work.
cons: Being a state employee means dealing with no raises, no flexibility, no chance for promotion as well as low departmental budgets.

review_title: WHY WOULD YOU DO THIS TO YOURSELF?
pros: It's academia, so you (theoretically) have brilliant people around you as colleagues.  The students are bright.    There is a beach, adequate shopping, and a thriving arts community.
cons: This used to be a wonderful place to work, but morale has gone down precipitously in the last 5 years.  No pay increases of substance for a decade, little or no support for teaching or research, academic freedom non-existent, no support when Millennial students throw tantrums because they don't earn an A grade, and a lack of respect for faculty from students and administration.   Professors who have the opportunity generally leave after a couple years.     Take a job here only if you can't get any other.

pros: The nearby beach.
cons: Faculty are treated like dirt, esp. adjunct, retired, and tenured.   Once you have tenure, the administration thinks you are stuck; you are not.   If you are wise, you'll look elsewhere.  Administrative bloat is a serious problem here and the benefits are so terrible that they are effectively nil.    While tenure is arguably based on teaching, publications, and service, the only one that really counts is number of Cabell's publications (quality of publication is not a factor).   Donate significantly and you'll get better treatment.   Academic freedom is such a problem here (i.e., non-existent) that the university was sued by a faculty member (not this reviewer) and the case settled (to university detriment).   Gender discrimination is common here.

review_title: Great place to work for the last 14 years
pros: Great mission, great people, dynamic work environment. I get to constantly explore new technologies and help make decisions in IT that impact the entire campus.  We get a lot of time off around the holidays, longevity pay, and vacation leave increases the longer you stick around.  The university environment is an exciting place to work and I've really enjoyed seeing the place evolve.
cons: We depend largely on the legislature for raises, which have been very little lately.

review_title: What you would expect from the State
pros: Young people around, lots of cultural and entertainment opportunities, access to campus facilities, decent health coverage and PTO
cons: The young people often aren't co-workers, just students, it's a state university - can be very slow and bureaucratic, very slim some incompetence involved, policies and procedures difficult to navigate - no two departments alike

review_title: Great place to work, but the pay is not great
pros:
* Relaxed atmosphere

cons:
* The NC state budget has been in deficit for many years now, which translates to no cost of living raises for employees. Too many employees are earning 80% or less of what they should be.
* No such thing as a merit raise or promotion.

pros: Almost every staff and faculty member that I came into contact with over the course of the two and a half years that I was a graduate assistant on campus was so helpful and kind. Both departments that I worked in truly had a team atmosphere.
cons: It's really hard to get a job here. There is a list a mile long of part time employees who have been waiting years to be full time, and for every open position in general. But I suppose that's most of Higher Ed.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Wilmington, NC
pros: Lots of freedom (as in, no guidance at all in shaping the classes/syllabi, which I actually liked), loved working with students/teaching uni classes as a graduate student, and they do some community-building events, which are fun. Like any other program, you do get the opportunity to meet like-minded people and develop your skill set. Some professors definitely changed my life and helped me grow as a person and writer.
cons:
Like any other university system these days, UNCW takes what it can get from you then spits you out. Way too low pay for the amount of work we were expected to do (teaching multiple classes on top of our own classes and thesis) and not enough guidance/instruction/help/advice from professors. There WERE exceptions to this, but for the most part, felt like I didn't get what I paid for--and left with debt on top of it. While I thought the admins tried to listen to us and our concerns, I didn't really see them act on any of them, at least not in any long-term solutions way, and this ranges from unprofessional behavior to stuff I can't write out. I know many other students felt this way and had conversations with leaders, but ultimately, if nothing changes, does it matter that they listened? 

Really recommend that would-be GTAs at UNCW do some very realistic budgeting to figure out whether it's worth it. What you're getting paid will mean you'll have to take on other jobs to get through it, and even then, you will probably leave with debt unless you are coming in wealthy already. On top of that, what kind of job market are you entering? UNCW is also known for not hiring connected people. As in, if you've been a GTA, they're NOT going to hire you for a bigger/better position after you graduate--EVEN IF YOU ARE THE BEST CANDIDATE. Have seen this happen, so don't get looped in thinking you'll build a relationship with them and have any chance of staying on at your underpaid job after you graduate--you will not be given a pass to stay, at least not for long and, again, not for a wage you can live on without other jobs.

pros: The staff is very understanding and laid back while still maintaining a very professional atmosphere.
